revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=July 2013}} {{Use British English|date=July 2013}} [[File:2007-Map-Avianflu-zones.png|right|thumb|200px|Map of the zones during the outbreak.]] The '''2007 Bernard Matthews H5N1 outbreak''' was an occurrence of [[avian influenza]] in England caused by the [[H5N1]] subtype of [[Influenza virus A]] that began on 30 January 2007. The infection affected poultry at one of [[Bernard Matthews Farms|Bernard Matthews]]' farms in [[Holton, Suffolk|Holton]] in [[Suffolk]]. It was the third instance of H5N1-subtype detected in the [[United Kingdom]] and a range of precautions were instituted to prevent spread of the disease including a large cull of [[turkey (bird)|turkey]]s, the imposition of segregation zones, and a disinfection programme for the plant.
The cause of the outbreak was not determined. However, it was considered significant that Bernard Matthews regularly transports turkeys and turkey products between the UK and its plant in [[Hungary]], and that the H5N1 strains previously found in Hungary, and those found at Suffolk, were effectively genetically identical.
==Background==
===H5N1=== {{H5N1}} {{main article|H5N1}} H5N1 is a subtype of the [[Influenzavirus A|Influenza A virus]], the viruses responsible for [[influenza]] in humans and many other animal species.<ref name=ICTV46.0.1>{{cite web | author=[[International Committee on Taxonomy of Viruses]] | publisher= | year=2002 | url=https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/ICTVdb/ICTVdB/46010000.htm | title=46.0.1. Influenzavirus A | accessdate=2006-04-17 }}</ref> A bird-adapted strain of H5N1, called ''HPAI A(H5N1)'' for "highly [[pathogen]]ic avian influenza virus of type A of subtype H5N1", is the causative agent of [[transmission and infection of H5N1|H5N1 flu]].
HPAI A(H5N1) is considered an avian disease, although there is some evidence of limited human-to-human transmission of the virus.<ref>{{cite journal |vauthors=Ungchusak K, Auewarakul P, Dowell SF |title=Probable person-to-person transmission of avian influenza A (H5N1) |journal=N Engl J Med |volume=352 |issue=4 |pages=333–40 |date=January 2005 |pmid=15668219 |doi=10.1056/NEJMoa044021 |url=|display-authors=etal}}</ref> A risk factor for contracting the virus is handling of infected poultry, but transmission of the virus from infected birds to humans is inefficient.<ref>{{cite journal |vauthors=Ortiz JR, Katz MA, Mahmoud MN |title=Lack of evidence of avian-to-human transmission of avian influenza A (H5N1) virus among poultry workers, [[Kano]], [[Nigeria]], 2006 |journal=J Infect Dis |volume=196 |issue=11 |pages=1685–91 |date=December 2007 |pmid=18008254 |doi=10.1086/522158 |url=|display-authors=etal}}</ref> Poultry farming practices have changed due to H5N1.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cfr.org/pub8198/laurie_garrett_anthony_s_fauci_michael_osterholm_rita_colwell/the_threat_of_global_pandemics.php|title=Council on Foreign Relations|accessdate=15 February 2007 <!--DASHBot-->|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20081013053617/http://www.cfr.org/pub8198/laurie_garrett_anthony_s_fauci_michael_osterholm_rita_colwell/the_threat_of_global_pandemics.php|archive-date=13 October 2008|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}}</ref> The cost of poultry farming has increased, while the cost to consumers has gone down, due to fears from H5N1 driving demand below supply.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.irinnews.org/report.aspx?reportid=26238 |title=Poultry sector suffers despite absence of bird flu |accessdate=29 December 2007 <!--DASHBot--> |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071217215838/http://www.irinnews.org/report.aspx?reportid=26238 |archivedate=17 December 2007 |deadurl=no |df=dmy }}</ref>
===Recent outbreaks in the UK and rest of EU=== The outbreak was the third instance of H5N1 detected in the United Kingdom. The first outbreak occurred in October 2005 among exotic birds imported from Taiwan and South America at a privately owned quarantine facility in [[Essex, England]].<ref>[http://www.defra.gov.uk/animalh/diseases/notifiable/disease/ai/pdf/ai-epidemrep111105.pdf "Epidemiology Report on Avian Influenza in Quarantine Premises Essex"] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070205044222/http://www.defra.gov.uk/animalh/diseases/notifiable/disease/ai/pdf/ai-epidemrep111105.pdf |date=5 February 2007 }}, DEFRA, 11 November 2005</ref><ref>[http://www.ingentaconnect.com/content/aibs/bio/2006/00000056/00000003/art00002 "Bird flu outbreak in United Kingdom reveals global vulnerabilities"], JP Dudley BIOSCIENCE March 2006</ref> The second instance involved a dead [[whooper swan]] found to have the virus in [[Cellardyke]], Scotland in April 2006.<ref>[http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk/4882946.stm "Swan tests confirm deadly virus"], BBC News, 6 April 2006</ref><ref>[http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/uk_news/4898398.stm "Bird flu swan was from outside UK"], BBC News, 11 April 2006</ref> A corresponding incidence on a farm in south-eastern Hungary was confirmed by the [[European Commission]] on 25 January 2007.<ref>[http://www.focus-fen.net/index.php?id=n104242 "Bird flu approaching Romanian border"], FOCUS News Agency, 25 January 2007</ref>
==The outbreak== Initial signs of the outbreak occurred on Tuesday, 30 January when 55 turkey poults died and 16 had to be killed because they were sick. At least 185 more died the following day.<ref>[http://www.ens-newswire.com/ens/feb2007/2007-02-05-01.asp "Britain Culls 159,000 Turkeys in Outbreak of H5N1 Bird Flu"], Environment News Service, 5 February 2007</ref>
It was not until 1 February that the deaths were reported to [[Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs|Defra]]. The farm was sealed off while tests were carried out, on samples taken from the dead birds, at the Veterinary Laboratories Agency in [[Weybridge]], [[Surrey]]. Another 1,500 birds died on 2 February.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thisislondon.co.uk/news/article-23384160-details/Bernard%20Matthews%20took%2048%20hours%20to%20report%20turkey%20deaths/article.do|title=Bernard Matthews took 48 hours to report turkey deaths|date=2007-02-03|accessdate=2007-02-04|publisher=[[The Evening Standard]] (thisislondon.com)|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070524052223/http://www.thisislondon.co.uk/news/article-23384160-details/Bernard%20Matthews%20took%2048%20hours%20to%20report%20turkey%20deaths/article.do|archive-date=24 May 2007|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}}</ref> Then on 3 February 2007 the H5N1 causation was confirmed.<ref>{{cite news|title=Vets work to contain bird flu (Video)|url = http://www.bbc.co.uk/mediaselector/check/player/nol/newsid_6320000/newsid_6328900?redirect=6328957.stm&news=1&bbram=1&bbwm=1&nbwm=1&nbram=1|date=2007-02-04|accessdate=2007-02-04}}</ref>
A 3 km protection zone, 10 km surveillance zone and a restricted zone encompassing 2000 km<sup>2</sup> were set up.<ref>{{cite news|title=Tests show bird flu is H5N1 virus|url = http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/england/suffolk/6327193.stm|date=2007-02-03|accessdate=2007-02-03 | work=BBC News| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20070205042118/http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/england/suffolk/6327193.stm| archivedate= 5 February 2007 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref> Another 159,000 turkeys were slaughtered with the [[Culling|cull]] being completed on the evening of 5 February. Also on 5 February there was criticism that nearby farmers had not been advised as to the action to be taken.<ref>[http://new.edp24.co.uk/content/news/story.aspx?brand=EDPOnline&category=News&tBrand=EDPOnline&tCategory=news&itemid=NOED05%20Feb%202007%2012%3A19%3A58%3A420 "Little risk for Bernard Matthews workers"] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070602202528/http://new.edp24.co.uk/content/news/story.aspx?brand=EDPOnline&category=News&tBrand=EDPOnline&tCategory=news&itemid=NOED05%20Feb%202007%2012%3A19%3A58%3A420 |date=2 June 2007 }}, Sarah Brealey, EDP 24, 5 February 2007</ref> Around 320 workers at the plant were given anti-viral drugs. Although a vet from the site was admitted into hospital, suffering from a 'mild respiratory illness' during the evening of 6 February, it was found not to be bird flu.<ref>[http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk/6337575.stm "Vet tests negative for bird flu"], BBC News, 7 February 2007</ref> The plant was thoroughly disinfected, with cleaning complete on 12 February, and permission being given for production to resume.<ref>[http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/uk_news/6334239.stm "Clean-up begins at bird flu farm"], BBC News, 6 February 2007</ref><ref>[https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/main.jhtml?xml=/news/2007/02/12/nbflu612.xml "Farm hit by bird-flu to reopen"], Natalie Paris, Daily Telegraph, 12 December 2007</ref>
It emerged in a highly critical report from [[Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs|Defra]] that there was a series of biosecurity failings at the Holton plant, some of which were drawn to the company's attention in the past. These included "gulls were taking turkey waste to roosts on top of the turkey-house 500 m away" and "holes in the turkey houses could have allowed in birds or rodents".<ref name=failings/><ref>[https://www.theguardian.com/birdflu/story/0,,2015217,00.html?gusrc=rss&feed=11 "String of flaws found at Bernard Matthews plant"], John Vidal, The Guardian, 17 February 2007</ref> [[Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs|Defra]] [[Minister (government)|minister]] [[Jeff Rooker, Baron Rooker|Jeff Rooker]] stated in a [[House of Lords]] debate on 22 February that the outbreak was "exclusively a Bernard Matthews Holton problem".<ref>[https://archive.is/20120904015254/http://www.fwi.co.uk/Articles/2007/03/02/102056/avian-flu-outbreak-is-exclusively-a-bernard-matthews.html "Avian flu outbreak is "exclusively a Bernard Matthews" problem"], Farmers Weekly, 2 March 2007</ref>
==Hungarian connection== The [[Her Majesty's Government|Government]], on 8 February, admitted that the outbreak may have been caused by semi-processed turkey meat imported directly from [[Hungary]], where the disease is prevalent, despite earlier in the week the [[Secretary of State for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs|Environment Secretary]], [[David Miliband]] assuring the [[British House of Commons|House of Commons]] that there was "no Hungarian connection".<ref>{{cite news |first=Michael |last=McCarthy |title=Bird flu may be linked to meat from Hungary, says Government |work=The Independent |date=2007-02-09 }}</ref>
Bernard Matthews had been importing 38 tons of partly processed turkey meat on a weekly basis from their Saga Foods company, in [[Sárvár]], Hungary, to a processing plant next to the farm. Though Saga Foods lies {{convert|165|mi|km}} from where the recent Hungarian H5N1 outbreak had occurred, a [[Board of directors|company director]] admitted it was "possible" that some of the meat could have come from the exclusion zone. In response to this revelation, [[Her Majesty's Government|Whitehall]] expressed concern over [[biosecurity]] and whether any meat may have been distributed for human consumption in Britain.<ref>[https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/main.jhtml;jsessionid=GUZPYQEQUVWB1QFIQMGSFF4AVCBQWIV0?xml=/news/2007/02/09/nflu109.xml "Bird flu plant imported turkey from Hungary"], Charles Clover, The Daily Telegraph, 9 February 2007</ref> On 9 February 2007 the Hungarian authorities started an investigation to try to establish whether there was a connection between the Suffolk and Hungarian outbreaks.<ref>[http://www.alertnet.org/thenews/newsdesk/L09621207.htm "Hungary investigates British bird flu link"], Reuters, 9 February 2007</ref> On 11 February the investigation revealed that turkey products were still being transported, in both directions, between the plant and Hungary with [[European Union regulation|EU regulations]] being cited as the reason why a transport ban could not be imposed.<ref>[https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/main.jhtml?xml=/news/2007/02/12/nbflu12.xml " Britain is powerless to stop turkey imports"], David Derbyshire, Daily telegraph, 12 February 2007</ref>
The Hungary link was dismissed by the [[European Commission]] on 12 February.<ref>[https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/main.jhtml?xml=/news/2007/02/12/nbflu512.xml "Bird flu at farm not linked to Hungary"], Natalie Paris, Daily Telegraph, 12 February 2007</ref> Even so, the H5N1 bird flu strains found in Hungary and Britain were shown to be 99.96% genetically identical and, according to an analysis of the viruses by the [[Veterinary Laboratories Agency]] in [[Weybridge]], [[Surrey]], were almost certainly linked.<ref>[http://politics.guardian.co.uk/homeaffairs/story/0,,2012525,00.html#article_continue "Tests confirm bird flu link to Hungary"], John Vidal, The Guardian, 14 February 2007</ref> A leak from the Government's [[Cabinet Office Briefing Rooms|COBRA]] emergency committee indicated that the authorities were not aware of the Hungarian connection until an investigator found a Gallfoods delivery wrapper in a Bernard Matthews bin. This raised the possibility that the outbreak was due to a "third party [[abattoir]], Gallfoods in [[Hungary]], just outside the restricted zone". This abattoir might have been a middle man for contaminated poultry farming tools, feed, or product from within the restricted zone, such as a Bernard Matthews owned subsidiary in Hungary.<ref>[http://www.thisislondon.co.uk/news/article-23385313-details/Did+Matthews+try+to+hide+turkey+imports/article.do "Did Matthews try to hide turkey imports?"] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070525021317/http://www.thisislondon.co.uk/news/article-23385313-details/Did+Matthews+try+to+hide+turkey+imports/article.do |date=25 May 2007 }}, Evening Standard, 12 February 2007</ref>
In response to the incident and allegations of a cover-up, [[Bernard Trevor Matthews|Bernard Matthews]] himself stated on 14 February "I'm sorry - but this has not been of our making. There's been absolutely no cover up at our end. I've been upset about allegations that we may have withheld information. That is completely untrue."<ref>[https://www.mirror.co.uk/news/topstories/tm_headline=matthews%2D-not-my-fault%26method=full%26objectid=18623646%26siteid=89520-name_page.html "Matthews: Not my fault"], Victoria Ward, Daily Mirror, 15 February 2007</ref>
Bernard Matthews was given permission to resume its shipments of poultry between the UK and Hungary from 17 February even though Defra indicated that Hungarian turkey products remained the "most plausible" cause of the outbreak.<ref name=failings>[http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/news/uk/article1395903.ece "Bernard Matthews faces prosecution for failures at bird flu plant"], Philippe Naughton, Times Online, 16 February 2007</ref>
==Consequences== By 8 February there was a lengthening list of countries that had banned the [[importation]] of [[poultry]] products from [[United Kingdom|Britain]] including South Africa, Russia, Japan, and many others but a spokesman for the [[European Commission]] condemned the bans as "totally disproportionate" and the British Poultry Council pointed out that exports were less than 9% of the level of domestic sales.<ref>[http://www.dailytimes.com.pk/default.asp?page=2007%5C02%5C09%5Cstory_9-2-2007_pg5_19 "UK poultry import bans"], Pakistan Daily Times, 9 February 2007 See also: [http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/news/uk/article1342148.ece "EU slams bans on British poultry"], Mark Bridge, Times Online, 6 February 2007</ref> [[Supermarket]] sales of Bernard Matthews branded turkeys halved after the onset of the outbreak as shoppers sought out alternatives. One of the biggest ongoing surveys of consumer confidence revealed that, by 13 February 2007, Bernard Matthews was the least respected and trusted brand in Britain.<ref>[https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/main.jhtml?xml=/news/2007/02/14/nbflu14.xml "Bernard Matthews loses sales"], Daily Telegraph, 14 February 2007</ref>
Following the outbreak the company confirmed, on 19 February 2007, that 130 workers would be [[Layoff|laid off]] for a period of twenty days due to a drop in product sales.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk/6376459.stm|title=Bernard Matthews staff 'laid off'|publisher=[[BBC News]] | date=2007-02-19 | accessdate=2010-01-01}}</ref> The [[Transport and General Workers' Union]] then called for the government to provide compensation to the workers affected.<ref>{{cite web| url= http://www.tgwu.org.uk/Templates/News.asp?NodeID=93155&int1stParentNodeID=42438&int2ndParentNodeID=89396&Action=Display| title= Workers must be compensated for Bernard Matthews lay offs| publisher= Transport and General Workers' Union| accessdate= 19 February 2007 }}{{Dead link|date=September 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> The Transport and General Workers' Union paid out hardship monies from union funds to union members, on top of any state benefits to which the laid-off workers were entitled and a one-off £100 payment from Bernard Matthews.<ref>{{cite journal |last=Berry |first=Mike |date=April 2007 |title=T&G union calls for more compensation for culled workforce after Bernard Matthews gets £600,000 for dead turkeys |journal=Personnel Today }}</ref>
A row broke out on 1 March 2007 when it emerged that the Government were paying compensation to the company for the 159,000 culled turkeys while laid-off workers were receiving nothing. At £3.75 each for hens and £3.53 for toms, the payout was then estimated at between £537,000 and £570,000.<ref>[http://new.edp24.co.uk/content/news/story.aspx?brand=EDPOnline&category=News&tBrand=edponline&tCategory=news&itemid=NOED02%20Mar%202007%2018%3A28%3A07%3A073 "Bernard Matthews to get £600,000 compensation"] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070927173234/http://new.edp24.co.uk/content/news/story.aspx?brand=EDPOnline&category=News&tBrand=edponline&tCategory=news&itemid=NOED02%20Mar%202007%2018:28:07:073 |date=27 September 2007 }}, Sarah Brealey, Norfolk Eastern Daily Press, 2 March 2007</ref><ref>[https://www.mirror.co.uk/news/topstories/tm_headline=anger-at-bernard-matthews---500-000-bird-flu-pay-out&method=full&objectid=18695171&siteid=89520-name_page.html "Anger at Bernard Matthews' £500,000 Bird Flu Pay-Out"], Louise Male, Daily Mirror, 2 March 2007</ref> In the event, though, the actual compensation bill came out at £589,356.89.<ref>[https://archive.is/20120802185714/http://www.fwi.co.uk/Articles/2007/04/19/103117/bernard-matthews-gets-nearly-600000-in-bird-flu-compensation.html "Bernard Matthews gets nearly £600,000 in bird flu compensation"], Farmers Weekly, 19 April 2007</ref> The crisis cost Bernard Matthews at least £20 m in lost sales and costs.<ref>[http://www.eveningnews24.co.uk/content/news/story.aspx?brand=ENOnline&category=News&tBrand=ENOnline&tCategory=news&itemid=NOED20%20Apr%202007%2008%3A54%3A57%3A410 "Fury over Bernard Matthews compensation"], Norwich Evening News, 20 April 2007</ref>
==See also== {{portal|Viruses}} * [[Redgrave, Suffolk#H5N1 outbreak in Redgrave, 2007|Redgrave 2007 outbreak]]

sp.: [[World Health Organization]], per [[MOS:CONSISTENCY]], proper names use the subject's own spelling (via [[WP:JWB]])
revision.text:
{{original research|date=March 2018}} {{Infobox organization | logo = American_Society_for_Nutrition.jpg | headquarters = Rockville, MD | leader_title = CEO | leader_name = John E. Courtney, PhD | name = American Society for Nutrition | abbreviation = ASN | merger = American Society for Nutritional Sciences, American Society for Clinical Nutrition, Society for International Nutrition | website = http://www.nutrition.org }} The '''American Society for Nutrition''' (ASN) is an American society for professional researchers and practitioners in the field of [[nutrition]]. ASN publishes four journals in the field of nutrition{{cite web |url=https://nutrition.org/publications/}}. It has been criticized for its financial ties to the food and beverage industry.{{Cite web| last = Eng| first = Monica| title = Should Coke sponsor nutrition research?| work = WBEZ| accessdate = 2018-08-23| url = https://www.wbez.org/shows/wbez-news/do-big-food-companies-have-too-much-sway-over-nutrition-research/43df1b4d-259b-4d15-a85f-59b77232068d}} == History == In 1928 a group of United States biochemists and physiologists grouped together to form the first scientific society focused on nutrition, the American Institute for Nutrition. The Society held its first meeting at the [[Cornell Medical School]] in 1934. The society was renamed the American Society for Nutritional Sciences in 1996.{{cite web | url=http://www.mc.vanderbilt.edu/diglib/sc_diglib/americansociety/index.html | title=The Nutrition Society Celebrates Its 75th Anniversary | publisher=Vanderbilt University Medical Center | accessdate=30 September 2015}} In 2005, the American Society for Nutritional Sciences, the American Society for Clinical Nutrition (established 1961); and the Society for International Nutrition (established 1996) merged to form The American Society for Nutrition (ASN).{{citation needed|date=August 2018}} ASN currently (2015) has a membership of about 5,000. It is one of the constituent societies comprising the [[Federation of American Societies for Experimental Biology]], a non-profit organization that is the principal umbrella organization of U.S. societies in the field of biological and medical research. In October 2010, the [[American College of Nutrition]] and American Society for Nutrition proposed to merge.[[American College of Nutrition#cite note-2|[2]]]{{Update inline|date=August 2018}} ==="Smart Choices" program=== The ASN administered the "[[Nutritional rating systems#Smart Choices Program|Smart Choices"]] food labelling program,{{Cite news| issn = 0458-3035| last = MacVean| first = Mary| title = 'Smart Choice' food label: a sign of nutrition or marketing?| work = Los Angeles Times| date = 2009-09-29}} which was suspended in 2009 after criticism.{{Cite news| issn = 0362-4331| last = Neuman| first = William| title = ‘Smart Choices’ Food Labeling Loses Support| work = The New York Times| accessdate = 2018-08-24| date = 2009-10-23| url = https://www.nytimes.com/2009/10/24/business/24food.html}} == Publications == ASN publishes four academic journals. Both publisher and some editorial staff accept funding from food industry organizations. {| cellpadding=5 class="wikitable sortable" |- !Journal title !! Year of founding !! 2016 [[impact factor]] |- |''[[The American Journal of Clinical Nutrition]]''|| 1952 || 6.926 |- |''[[Advances in Nutrition]]''|| 2010 || 5.233 |- |''[[The Journal of Nutrition]]''|| 1928 || 4.145 |- |''[http://cdn.nutrition.org Current Developments in Nutrition]''|| 2017 || ? |} The 2017 ''[http://cdn.nutrition.org Current Developments in Nutrition]'' is an [[open-access]] journal aiming for rapid publication and a broader range of topics than the ASN's other journals.{{citation needed|date=August 2018}} == Memberships and sustaining partners == === Membership === Eligibility for membership: *Regular Members - Any individual with a doctoral-level degree and suitable scholarly achievements, as determined by the Board of Directors *Associate Members - Any individual with a doctoral-level degree, or relevant professional accomplishments, as determined by the Board of Directors *Student Members - Any individual who is a candidate for an undergraduate, graduate, or medical degree *Emeritus Members - Any member age 65 years or older may apply to the Board of Directors for Emeritus Membership *Young Professional / Postdoctoral Members - Any individual within three years of receiving a doctorate, medical degree, or other degree in nutrition or a related field{{cite web | url=http://www.nutrition.org/about-asn/mission-and-bylaws/#purpose | title=Mission and ByLaws | publisher=The American Society for Nutritional Sciences | accessdate=28 September 2015}} === Sponsors === ASN uses the term "Sustaining Partners" for corporate sponsors donating over $10,000 per year. According to their website:
Industry companies with the highest level of commitment to the nutrition profession are recognized as '''Sustaining Partners of the American Society for Nutrition'''. Engage with ASN as a Sustaining Partner today, and benefit from a number of advantages! Recognition includes print and online exposure, annual meeting benefits, and the ability to sponsor educational opportunities, grants and other items. However, you will derive the greatest benefit by aligning your company with ASN's superlative scientific reputation.{{cite web | url=http://www.nutrition.org/our-members/corporate-members/ | title=Corporate Members | publisher=The American Society for Nutrition | accessdate=28 September 2015}}
The American Society for Nutrition's sustaining partners, as listed on its website as of March 2018, are:https://nutrition.org/sustaining-partners/ [[Abbott Nutrition]], [[Almond Board of California]], [[Bayer HealthCare]], [[Biofortis]] Clinical Research, [[California Walnut Commission]], [[Cargill, Inc.]], [[Corn Refiners Association]], [[Council for Responsible Nutrition]], [[Dairy Research Institute]], [[DSM Nutritional Products]] (LLC), [[DuPont]] Nutrition & Health,apparently this DuPont, miscapitalized on the website: http://www.dupont.com/corporate-functions/our-company/businesses/nutrition-and-health.html the ''Egg Nutrition Center'' of the [[American Egg Board]],https://eggnutritioncenter.org/about/ [[General Mills]] Bell Institute of Health and Nutrition, [[Herbalife]]/Herbalife Nutrition Institute, [[International Bottled Water Foundation]], [[Kellogg Company]], [[Kyowa Hakko]] USA Inc., [[Mars Inc.]], [[McCormick Science Institute]],http://mccormickscienceinstitute.com/ [[Mondelez]] International Technical Center, [[Monsanto Company]], [[National Cattlemen's Beef Association]] (a contractor to "The Beef Checkoff"), [[Nestlé]] Nutrition, Medical Affairs, [[PepsiCo]], [[Pfizer, Inc.]], [[Pharmavite]] (LLC), [[Tate & Lyle]], [[The a2 Milk Company]], [[The Coca Cola Company]], [[The Dannon Company]] Inc., [[The Sugar Association]], and [[Unilever]]. == Corporate relationship concerns == The ASN has [[conflicts of interest|conflicting interests]] in taking funding from food industry marketing groups while providing unbiassed information on nutrition; these conflicting interests have caused criticism and concerns of bias.{{Cite web| last = O’Connor| first = Anahad| title = Coca-Cola Funds Scientists Who Shift Blame for Obesity Away From Bad Diets| work = Well| accessdate = 2018-03-24| date = 2015-08-09| url = https://well.blogs.nytimes.com/2015/08/09/coca-cola-funds-scientists-who-shift-blame-for-obesity-away-from-bad-diets/}}{{Cite journal| doi = 10.1016/j.nutres.2016.10.006| issn = 0271-5317| volume = 36| issue = 11| pages = 1183–1192| last1 = Rucker| first1 = Robert B.| last2 = Rucker| first2 = Michael R.| title = Nutrition: ethical issues and challenges| journal = Nutrition Research| accessdate = 2018-03-31|date=November 2016| url = http://linkinghub.elsevier.com/retrieve/pii/S0271531716302081}} ASN actions have also been criticized for being better-aligned with the nutritional advice of sponsors than the advice of the [[World Health Organization]] and other public health, public interest, and government organizations.{{Cite web| last = Bellatti| first = Andy| title = OPINION: Industry-funded nutrition groups shouldn’t dictate health policy| accessdate = 2018-03-31| date = 2015-06-24| url = http://america.aljazeera.com/opinions/2015/6/industry-funded-nutrition-groups-shouldnt-dictate-health-policy.html}}{{Cite web| last1 = Mustain| first1 = Patrick| last2 = Mustain| first2 = Patrick| title = Science for Sale: Big Food's Influence on Top Nutrition Research Org| work = Scientific American Blog Network| date = June 15, 2015 |accessdate = 2018-03-31| url = https://blogs.scientificamerican.com/food-matters/science-for-sale-big-food-s-influence-on-top-nutrition-research-org/}} Long-time member [[Marion Nestle]] has voiced concerns about what she sees as a "too-cozy relationship with food company sponsors" within the organization.{{cite web | url=http://www.foodpolitics.com/2015/06/the-food-industrys-undue-influence-on-the-american-society-for-nutrition/ | title=The food industry’s undue influence on the American Society for Nutrition | publisher=Marion Nestle | date=23 June 2015 | accessdate=26 September 2015 | author=Nestle, Marion}} In a 2015 report, [[Michele Simon]] also voiced concerns regarding corporate involvement with the society.{{cite web | url=http://www.eatdrinkpolitics.com/wp-content/uploads/ASNReportFinal.pdf | title=Nutrition Scientists on the Take from Big Food | publisher=EatDrink Politics | date=September 2015 | accessdate=28 September 2015 | author=Simon, Michele}}{{Cite web| title = Leading U.S. Nutrition Scientists Forge Cozy Relationships With Major Food Companies and Lobbying Groups, Report Charges| work = International Business Times| accessdate = 2018-08-24| date = 2015-06-15| url = https://www.ibtimes.com/leading-us-nutrition-scientists-forge-cozy-relationships-major-food-companies-1967006}} ==References== {{reflist}} == External links == *[http://www.nutrition.org Official '''American Society for Nutrition''' website] [[Category:Nutrition]] [[Category:Medical and health organizations based in Maryland]] [[Category:Scientific organizations established in 1928]] [[Category:1928 establishments in Maryland]] [[Category:Food science institutes]]

revision.comment: Rescuing 1 sources and tagging 0 as dead. #IABot (v2.0beta9)
revision.text:
'''Amnesic shellfish poisoning''' ('''ASP''') is an illness caused by consumption of the marine biotoxin called [[domoic acid]].<ref name=uhm>{{ cite journal |author1=Clark, R. F. |author2=Williams, S. R. |author3=Nordt, S. P. |author4=Manoguerra, A. S. | title = A Review of Selected Seafood Poisonings | journal = Undersea and Hyperbaric Medicine | year = 1999 | volume = 26 | issue = 3 | pages = 175–184 | pmid = 10485519 | url = http://archive.rubicon-foundation.org/2314 }}</ref> In [[mammal]]s, including humans, domoic acid acts as a [[neurotoxin]], causing permanent [[short-term memory loss]], [[brain damage]], and death in severe cases.
This toxin is produced naturally by marine [[diatom]]s belonging to the genus ''[[Pseudo-nitzschia]]'' and the species ''[[Nitzschia navis-varingica]]''.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.marinespecies.org/HAB/aphia.php?p%3Dtaxdetails%26id%3D246595 |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2012-05-17 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160917193614/http://www.marinespecies.org/hab/aphia.php?p=taxdetails&id=246595 |archivedate=2016-09-17 |df= }} ''Nitzschia navis-varingica'']</ref> When accumulated in high concentrations by shellfish during filter feeding, domoic acid can then be passed on to birds, marine mammals and humans via consumption of the contaminated shellfish.<ref>{{ cite book |author1=Bates, S. S. |author2=Trainer, V. L. | year = 2006 | chapter = The Ecology of Harmful Diatoms |editor1=Granéli, E. |editor2=Turner, J. | title = Ecology of Harmful Algae | series = Ecological Studies | volume = 189 | publisher = Springer-Verlag | location = Heidelberg | pages = 81–93 | doi = 10.1007/978-3-540-32210-8_7 | isbn = 978-3-540-74009-4 }}</ref><ref>{{ cite journal |author1=Bejarano, A. C. |author2=van Dola, F. M. |author3=Gulland, F. M. |author4=Rowles, T. K. |author5=Schwacke, L. H. | title = Production and Toxicity of the Marine Biotoxin Domoic Acid and its Effects on Wildlife: A Review | journal = Human and Ecological Risk Assessment | year = 2008 | volume = 14 | issue = 3 | pages = 544–567 | doi = 10.1080/10807030802074220 | url = http://www.marinemammalcenter.org/assets/pdfs/vetsci-stranding/scientific-contributions/2008/bejarano-2008-review-of-domoic-acid.pdf | format = pdf }}</ref><ref>{{ cite book |author1=Trainer, V. L. |author2=Hickey, B. M. |author3=Bates, S. S. | year = 2008 | chapter = Toxic Diatoms |editor1=Walsh, P. J. |editor2=Smith, S. L. |editor3=Fleming, L. E. |editor4=Solo-Gabriele, H. |editor5=Gerwick, W. H. | title = Oceans and Human Health: Risks and Remedies from the Sea | publisher = Elsevier Science | location = New York | pages = 219–237 | isbn = 978-0-12-372584-4 }}</ref><ref>{{ cite journal |author1=Lefebvre, K. A. |author2=Robertson, A. | title = Domoic Acid and Human Exposure Risks: A Review | journal = Toxicon | year = 2010 | volume = 56 | issue = 2 | pages = 218–230 | pmid = 19505488 | doi=10.1016/j.toxicon.2009.05.034}}</ref><ref>{{ cite book |author1=Bargu, S. |author2=Smith, E. |author3=Ozhan, K. | year = 2011 | chapter = Toxic Diatom ''Pseudo-nitzschia'' and its Primary Consumers (Vectors) | pages = 493–512 |editor1=Seckbach, J. |editor2=Kociolek, P. | title = The Diatom World | publisher = Springer | isbn = 978-9400713260 }}</ref><ref>{{ cite journal |author1=Bargu, S. |author2=Goldstein, T. |author3=Roberts, K. |author4=Li, C. |author5=Gulland, F. | year = 2012 | title = ''Pseudo-nitzschia'' Blooms, Domoic Acid, and Related California Sea Lion Strandings in Monterey Bay, California | journal = Marine Mammal Science | volume = 28 | issue = 2 | pages = 237–253 | doi = 10.1111/j.1748-7692.2011.00480.x }}</ref><ref>{{ cite journal |author1=Lelong, A. |author2=Hégaret, H. |author3=Soudant, P. |author4=Bates, S. S. | year = 2012 | title = ''Pseudo-nitzschia'' (Bacillariophyceae) Species, Domoic Acid and Amnesic Shellfish Poisoning: Revisiting Previous Paradigms | journal = Phycologia | volume = 51 | issue = 2 | pages = 168–216 | doi = 10.2216/11-37.1 }}</ref><ref>{{ cite journal |author1=Trainer, V. L. |author2=Bates, S. S. |author3=Lundholm, N. |author4=Thessen, A. E. |author5=Cochlan, W. P. |author6=Adams, N. G. |author7=Trick, C. G. | year = 2012 | title = ''Pseudo-nitzschia'' Physiological Ecology, Phylogeny, Toxicity, Monitoring and Impacts on Ecosystem Health | journal = Harmful Algae | volume = 14 | pages = 271–300 | doi = 10.1016/j.hal.2011.10.025 }}</ref>
Although human illness due to domoic acid has only been associated with shellfish, the toxin can [[bioaccumulation|bioaccumulate]] in many [[ocean|marine]] organisms that consume [[phytoplankton]], such as [[anchovy|anchovies]] and [[sardine]]s. Intoxication by domoic acid in non-human organisms is frequently referred to as '''domoic acid poisoning''' or '''DAP'''.
== Symptoms and treatment == In the brain, domoic acid especially damages the [[hippocampus]] and [[amygdaloid nucleus]].<ref name=uhm/> It damages the [[neuron]]s by activating [[AMPA]] and [[kainate]] receptors, causing an influx of [[calcium]]. Although calcium flowing into cells is a normal event, the uncontrolled increase of calcium causes the cell to degenerate. See reviews by Ramsdell (2007)<ref>{{ cite book | author = Ramsdell, J. S. | year = 2007 | chapter = The Molecular and Integrative Basis to Domoic Acid Toxicity | editor = Botana, L. | title = Phycotoxins: Chemistry and Biochemistry | publisher = Wiley-Blackwell | location = Cambridge, MA | pages = 223–250 | isbn = 0-8138-2700-0 | doi = 10.1002/9780470277874.ch13 }}</ref> and Pulido (2008).<ref>{{ cite journal | author = Pulido, O. M. | title = Domoic Acid Toxicologic Pathology: A Review | journal = Marine Drugs | year = 2008 | volume = 6 | issue = 2 | pages = 180–219 | doi = 10.3390/md20080010 | pmc = 2525487 | pmid = 18728725 | url = http://www.mdpi.org/marinedrugs/papers/md6020180.pdf | format = pdf }}</ref>
Gastrointestinal symptoms can appear 24 hours after ingestion of affected molluscs. They may include [[vomiting]], [[nausea]], [[diarrhea]], abdominal cramps and haemorrhagic [[gastritis]]. In more severe cases, neurological symptoms can take several hours or up to three days to develop. These include [[headache]], [[dizziness]], [[disorientation]], vision disturbances, loss of short-term memory, motor weakness, [[seizure]]s, profuse respiratory secretions, [[hiccup]]s, unstable blood pressure, [[cardiac arrhythmia]] and [[coma]].
People poisoned with very high doses of the toxin or displaying risk factors such as old age and [[renal failure]] can die. Death has occurred in 4 of 107 confirmed cases. In a few cases, permanent [[sequela]]e included short-term memory loss and peripheral [[polyneuropathy]].
There is no known antidote available for domoic acid, so if symptoms fit the description, it is advised to go quickly to a hospital. Cooking or freezing affected fish or shellfish tissue does not lessen the toxicity. New research has found that domoic acid is a heat-resistant and very stable toxin which can damage kidneys at concentrations that are 100 times lower than what causes neurological effects.
== Discovery== ASP was first discovered in humans late in 1987, when a serious outbreak of food poisoning occurred in eastern [[Canada]].<ref name=uhm/><ref>{{ cite journal | author = Bates, S. S. | title = Pennate diatom ''Nitzschia pungens'' as the primary source of domoic acid, a toxin in shellfish from eastern Prince Edward Island, Canada | journal = Canadian Journal of Fisheries and Aquatic Sciences | year = 1989 | volume = 46 | issue = 7 | pages = 1203–1215 | doi = 10.1139/f89-156 | url = http://rparticle.web-p.cisti.nrc.ca/rparticle/AbstractTemplateServlet?calyLang=eng&journal=cjfas&volume=46&year=0&issue=7&msno=f89-156 |display-authors=etal}}{{dead link|date=October 2016 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> Three elderly patients died and other victims suffered long-term neurological problems. Because the victims suffered from memory loss, the term "amnesic" shellfish poisoning is used.<ref>{{ cite journal | author = Todd, E. C. D. | title = Domoic Acid and Amnesic Shellfish Poisoning: A Review | journal = Journal of Food Protection | year = 1993 | volume = 56 | issue = 1 | pages = 69–83 | doi = | url = http://agris.fao.org/agris-search/search/display.do?f=1993/US/US93087.xml;US9331144 }}</ref> The story made front-page newspaper headlines.
Epidemiologists from [[Health Canada]] quickly linked the illnesses to restaurant meals of cultured mussels harvested from one area in [[Prince Edward Island]], a place never before affected by toxic algae. Mouse bioassays on aqueous extracts of the suspect mussels caused death with some unusual neurotoxic symptoms very different from those of [[paralytic shellfish poisoning]] toxins and other known toxins. On December 12, 1987, a team of scientists was assembled at the [[National Research Council of Canada]] laboratory in [[City of Halifax|Halifax]], [[Nova Scotia]]. Integrating bioassay-directed fractionation with chemical analysis, the team identified the toxin on the afternoon of December 16, just 4 days after the start of the concerted investigation.<ref>{{ cite journal |author1=Quilliam M. A. |author2=Wright J. L. C. | title = The Amnesic Shellfish Poisoning Mystery | journal = Analytical Chemistry | year = 1989 | volume = 61 | issue = 18 | pages = 1053A–1060A | doi = 10.1021/ac00193a002 | pmid = 2802153 }}</ref><ref>{{ cite web | url = https://www2.glf.dfo-mpo.gc.ca/dapr-radp/docs/bird_et_al_-_identification_of_domoic_acid_-_arl_tech_rep_1988.pdf | format = pdf | title = Identification of Domoic Acid at National Research Council's Atlantic Lab | accessdate = 9 May 2012 }}{{dead link|date=October 2016 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref>
== Possible animal effects == On June 22, 2006, a [[Brown Pelican|California brown pelican]], possibly under the influence of domoic acid,<ref>[http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/13525699/ Possibly drunk bird hits windshield] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121104110829/http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/13525699/ |date=November 4, 2012 }}</ref> flew through the windshield of a car on the [[Pacific Coast Highway (US)|Pacific Coast Highway]]. The [[phycotoxin]] is found in the local coastal waters.
Since March 2007, marine mammal and seabird strandings and deaths off the Southern California coast have increased markedly. These incidents have been linked to the recent and dramatic increase of a naturally occurring toxin produced by algae. Most of the animals found dead tested positive for domoic acid.
According to the Channel Islands Marine and Wildlife Institute (CIMWI),<ref>[http://www.cimwi.org/stranded_domoic.html Domic Acid Information and History] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090513065206/http://www.cimwi.org/stranded_domoic.html |date=May 13, 2009 }}</ref> "It is generally accepted that the incidence of problems associated with toxic algae is increasing. Possible reasons to explain this increase include natural mechanisms of species dispersal (currents and tides) to a host of human-related phenomena such as nutrient enrichment (agricultural run-off), climate shifts or transport of algae species via ship ballast water."
== In popular culture == In the TV series ''[[Elementary (TV series)|Elementary]]'' episode "The Red Team" (original air date January 31, 2013), a witness is intentionally poisoned with domoic acid.
In the "[[List of Get a Life episodes|Bad Fish]]" episode of ''[[Get a Life (TV series)|Get a Life]]'' (original air-date: February 2, 1992), Sharon and Gus get amnesia after eating bad shellfish, and Chris seizes the opportunity to convince them that they are his best friends.
Domoic acid poisoning may have caused an August 18, 1961 invasion of thousands of frantic seabirds in [[Capitola, California|Capitola]] and [[Santa Cruz, California]].<ref>{{ cite journal |author1=Bargu, S. |author2=Silver, M. W. |author3=Ohman, M. D. |author4=Benitez-Nelson, C. R. |author5=Garrison, D. L. | year = 2012 | title = Mystery behind Hitchcock's Birds | journal = Nature Geoscience | volume = 5 | issue = 1 | pages = 2–3 | doi = 10.1038/ngeo1360 }}</ref> Director [[Alfred Hitchcock]] heard about this invasion while working on his adaptation of the [[Daphne du Maurier]] [[Novella|novelette]] "[[The Birds (story)|The Birds]]" for his feature film ''[[The Birds (film)|The Birds]]'' (1963), and asked the ''[[Santa Cruz Sentinel]]'' newspaper for any further news copy as "research for his new thriller."
==See also== * [[Diarrhetic shellfish poisoning]] (DSP) * [[Neurotoxic shellfish poisoning]] (NSP) * [[Paralytic shellfish poisoning]] (PSP) * [[Harmful algal bloom]]s (HABs)
== References == {{Reflist|40em}}
== External links == *[http://www.whoi.edu/redtide/page.do?pid=14275 Amnesic Shellfish Poisoning] at [[Woods Hole Oceanographic Institution]] *[https://web.archive.org/web/20131204023151/http://www.inter.dfo-mpo.gc.ca/Gulf/DAPR Domoic acid and ''Pseudo-nitzschia'' references] at [[Fisheries and Oceans Canada]] *[https://web.archive.org/web/20131203012507/http://www.issha.org/Welcome-to-ISSHA/Harmful-Algae-Links/Phycotoxins/Domoic-Acid-ASP Amnesic Shellfish Poisoning, Domoic Acid, and ''Pseudo-nitzschia'' links] at the [http://www.issha.org/Welcome-to-ISSHA ISSHA] website *[https://web.archive.org/web/20070630131126/http://www.inchem.org/documents/pims/chemical/pim670.htm Domoic acid] at [[International Programme on Chemical Safety]] *[http://wdfw.wa.gov/fish/shelfish/razorclm/domacid.htm DOMOIC ACID — A MAJOR CONCERN TO WASHINGTON STATE’S SHELLFISH LOVERS] at [[Washington Department of Fish and Wildlife]] *[https://web.archive.org/web/20071009103158/http://www.ibrrc.org/pr_04_25_2007.html Crisis off our coast] at the [https://web.archive.org/web/20100505234648/http://www.ibrrc.org/index.html International Bird Rescue Research Center] *[https://web.archive.org/web/20071109142639/http://healthebay.org/news/2007/04_30_domoicacid/default.asp Domoic Acid Poisoning Linked to Recent Marine Strandings and Deaths] at [http://www.healthebay.org/ Heal the Bay] *[https://web.archive.org/web/20090513065206/http://www.cimwi.org/stranded_domoic.html Domoic Acid Information and History] at the [https://archive.is/20070715143528/http://www.cimwi.org/index.html Channel Islands Marine and Wildlife Institute] {{Poisoning and toxicity}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Amnesic Shellfish Poisoning}} [[Category:Seafood]] [[Category:Medical emergencies]] [[Category:Toxic effect of noxious substances eaten as food]] [[Category:Neuroscience]]

revision.comment: Rescuing 0 sources and tagging 1 as dead. #IABot (v2.0beta10)
revision.text:
The '''British Society of Medical Hypnotists''' was an organization composed of professional [[Hypnotherapy|hypnotherapists]] located in [[London]].
The main objective the Society was to establish standards of practice regarding the use of [[hypnosis]] and [[hypnotherapy]]. The society was founded in 1948.<ref>[http://www.hypnos.co.uk/hypnomag/peltbook/chapter1p4.htm "The History of Hypnotism"] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110722010237/http://www.hypnos.co.uk/hypnomag/peltbook/chapter1p4.htm |date=July 22, 2011 }} by [[Sydney James van Pelt]], Magazine for Hypnosis and Hypnotherapy.</ref> [[Sydney van Pelt]] was the first and lifetime (until 1976) president of the Society.<ref>[http://www.durbinhypnosis.com/vanpelt.htm "A Tribute to Dr. Sidney J. Van Pelt (1976)"]{{Dead link|date=November 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> Its official organ was the ''[[British Journal of Medical Hypnotism]]''.<ref>[http://pacscl.exlibrisgroup.com:48998/F/?func=direct&doc_number=000130929 Entry] at the Historical Library and Wood Institute of [[The College of Physicians of Philadelphia]].</ref>
==References== <references/>
==External links== *[http://www.bsch.org.uk British Society of Clinical Hypnosis]
[[Category:Professional associations based in the United Kingdom]] [[Category:Hypnosis organizations]] [[Category:Medical and health organisations in London]] [[Category:1948 establishments in the United Kingdom]] [[Category:Medical and health organisations based in the United Kingdom]]
{{UK-org-stub}}

revision.comment: /* References */ {{List of EN standards|state=autocollapse}}
revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=June 2013}} '''CEN/CENELEC Guide 6: Guidelines for standards developers to address the needs of older persons and persons with disabilities''' is a document for participants in standardisation activities at [[European Committee for Standardization|CEN]] and [[European Committee for Electrotechnical Standardization|CENELEC]] that contains guidance for the creation and the revision of standards to ensure greater accessibility of products and services. The document is a "Guide", in other words, not a European Standard (EN).The abbreviation EN is derived from the German phrase {{lang|de|Europäische Norm}}. See the terminology used in [http://www.cen.eu/cenorm/aboutus/ar/ar07web.pdf Standards for a Better World. CEN Annual Report 2007] (in English, French and German), and the definitions in [http://www.cen.eu/boss/supporting/reference+documents/2008internalregulationpart2englishfinal.pdf CEN Internal Regulations Part 2: Common Rules for Standards Work]. The guide is identical to ISO/IEC Guide 71 and was adopted by both the CEN Technical Board and the CENELEC Technical Board, and published in January 2002. The adoption of CEN/CENELEC Guide 6 resulted from a European mandate to the European standardisation organisations, and the European Commission is funding projects to promote the use of the Guide. A revised version was published in December 2014; it is identical to ISO/IEC Guide 71:2014. ==Background== In 2000 [[International Organization for Standardization|ISO]] and IEC published the policy statement: "Addressing the needs of older persons and people with disabilities in standardization work".ISO/IEC: [http://www.iso.org/iso/iso_iec_gen3_2000-en.pdf Policy Statement: Addressing the needs of older persons and people with disabilities in standardization work]. Consulted 2009-07-23.A draft of this policy statement is available in an ANEC report: [http://www.anec.eu/attachments/Sn08-99.pdf Report from the COPOLCO WG on the Elderly and People with Disabilities]. March 1999. Accessed 2009-04-07. This policy statement recognised the need to include the requirements of older persons and persons with disabilities during the development and revision of standards. The document stated that this could be achieved by following the basic principles of: {{Quotation| * Universal or Accessible Design * consumer representation of older persons and people with disabilities; and * relevant information exchange.}} The policy statement also recommended using ISO/IEC Guide 71, which would become available in 2001. ISO/IEC Guide 71:2001: ''Guidelines for standardization to address the needs of older persons and people with disabilities''ISO & IEC: [http://www.iso.org/iso/iso_catalogue/catalogue_tc/catalogue_detail.htm?csnumber=33987 ISO/IEC Guide 71:2001]. [http://www.cettico.fi.upm.es/aenor/BTWG101-5(Sec)22.pdf Draft ISO/IEC Guide 71]. Accessed 2009-04-07. was published in 2001 and has been widely accepted:Anne Ferguson: "User Needs in Standards—Older People and People With Disabilities", in ''Handbook on Standards and Guidelines in Ergonomics and Human Factors'', edited by Waldemar Karwowski, Routledge/CRC Press, 2006, {{ISBN|978-0-8058-4129-9}}, p. 535. Consulted 2009-07-23.Ken Sagawa: "Accessible Design in Light and Lighting Guidelines for Lighting for the Elderly and People with Disabilities", [http://www.cie.org.au/news88.pdf CIE News, 88 (April 2009)]. Accessed 2009-09-29. it has been used in Japan{{Citation | last = Ito | first = Akira | title = ISO/IEC Guide 71 and Information Accessibility | date = 24 November 2004 | url = http://www.women.or.kr/data/20041124/%5BS3-1%5DAkira%20ITO.pdf | accessdate = 2009-07-23}} and was adopted by CEN and CENELEC as CEN/CENELEC Guide 6 (see below). ISO/IEC Guide 71 was also made available in Braille and was the first ISO publication that was made available in this format.ISO: "[http://www.iso.org/iso/fr/pressrelease.htm?refid=Ref820 {{lang|fr|Le Guide pour répondre aux besoins des personnes âgées et des personnes handicapées est maintenant disponible en Braille}}]" / "[http://www.iso.org/iso/pressrelease.htm?refid=Ref820 Guide to address the needs of the elderly and disabled now available in Braille]", press release, 2002-04-29. Consulted 2009-07-29. CEN and CENELEC adopted ISO/IEC Guide 71 as CEN/CENELEC Guide 6CEN/CENELEC: [ftp://ftp.cen.eu/BOSS/Reference_Documents/Guides/CEN_CLC/CEN_CLC_6.pdf CEN/CENELEC Guide 6: Guidelines for standards developers to address the needs of older persons and persons with disabilities]. Accessed 2009-04-07.[http://www.tiresias.org/research/guidelines/CEN%20guide%206/index.htm HTML version of CEN/CENELEC Guide 6] hosted at tiresias.org. Accessed 2009-04-07. as a result of Mandate M/283,M/283: Mandate to the European Standards Bodies for a guidance document in the field of safety and usability of products by people with special needs (e.g. elderly and disabled). Available on the [http://www.etsi.org/WebSite/document/aboutETSI/EC_Mandates/M283.pdf ETSI website]. Accessed 2009-04-07. which the [[European Commission]] and the [[European Fair Trade Association|European Fee Trade Association (EFTA)]] gave to the three official European standardisation bodies [[European Committee for Standardization|CEN]], [[European Committee for Electrotechnical Standardization|CENELEC]] and [[European Telecommunications Standards Institute|ETSI]]. The text of the Mandate pointed out that special needs were addressed in standards related to [[Assistive technology|assistive technologies]], but that {{Quotation|there is no formal structure or procedure ensuring that the needs of all consumers of all ages, with or without disabilities or special abilities, are catered for in the entire standardisation process. Individual standardisation committees do not spontaneously take into account safety and usability for people with disabilities and for elderly people, except if they draft specific standards for assistive products. If general standards for consumer products do not meet the requirements of these consumers with special needs, this means that many products and services cannot be used by a large part of the European population. }} Guide 6 is part of a wider framework that standardisation organisations can use to support the need for more [[Accessibility|accessible products and services]]. The [[International Organization for Standardization|ISO]]/IEC Policy Statement 2000 "Addressing the Needs of Older Persons and People with Disabilities in Standardization Work" already provided principles and considerations for ensuring that the needs of older persons and persons with disabilities are addressed in the standardisation process. ETSI, the third European standardisation body to which Mandate M/283 was addressed, did not adopt CEN/CENELEC Guide 6 but continued using ISO/IEC Guide 71 as a reference document. Since 2008 ISO/IEC Guide 71 has a supporting document: ISO/TR 22411:2008: ''Ergonomics data and guidelines for the application of ISO/IEC Guide 71 to products and services to address the needs of older persons and persons with disabilities''.[http://www.iso.org/iso/iso_catalogue/catalogue_tc/catalogue_detail.htm?csnumber=40933 ISO/TR 22411:2008: Ergonomics data and guidelines for the application of ISO/IEC Guide 71 to products and services to address the needs of older persons and persons with disabilities]. Accessed 2009-04-07 In December 2014 CEN and CENELEC adopted the revised ISO/IEC Guide 71: 2014 as CEN-CENELEC Guide 6:2014. This new version of Guide 6 is freely available on the website of CEN and CENELEC.CEN; CENELEC: "[http://www.cencenelec.eu/news/brief_news/Pages/TN-2014-026.aspx NEW Guide for addressing accessibility in standards]", 1 December 2014.European Committee for Standardization (CEN); European Committee for Electrotechnical Standardization (CENELEC): [ftp://ftp.cencenelec.eu/EN/EuropeanStandardization/Guides/6_CENCLCGuide6.pdf CEN-CENELEC GUIDE 6: Guide for addressing accessibility in standards]. Edition 2, 2014-12. ==Content== CEN/CENELEC Guide 6 is a document for participants in CEN technical bodies: Technical Committees or TCs, Working Groups or WGs, Task Forces, Workshops etcetera. These technical bodies are responsible for addressing the needs of persons with disabilities and older people in the standards, specifications, reports or other documents that they produce. CEN/CENELEC Guide 6 has three goals: # to inform how human abilities (and disabilities) affect the usability of products, services and the built environment, # to describe how requirements in standards relate to accessibility and usability of products and services, # to raise awareness about the benefits of accessible design. The Guide consists of a few introductory sections followed by 10 other chapters which are called "clauses". The most important chapters are described in the list below. # Clause 6 briefly describes a process that allows technical committees to consider the needs of older persons and persons with disabilities. It divides the standardisation process into five steps; for each step, the Guide lists one or more issues that need to be addressed. # Clause 7 and 8 provide tables that relate several types of clauses in a standard (for example, on packaging, the user interface and the built environment) to factors that need to be considered when addressing disabilities. # Clause 9 provides descriptions of body functions or disabilities and their implications when using products and services. # The last chapter is a bibliography that provides a list of resources for more specific guidance. ==Implementation and uptake== In December 2001, CEN and CENELEC published CEN/CENELEC Guide 2: "CEN/CENELEC Guide 2: Consumer interests and the preparation of standards", which is a republication of CEN/CENELEC Memorandum 2 from 1977.CEN/CENELEC: [http://www.cen.eu/boss/supporting/reference+documents/cclcgd002.pdf CEN/CENELEC Guide 2: Consumer interests and the preparation of standards]. Accessed 2009-06-24. This guide recommends member bodies of CEN and CENELEC to consult with [[Consumer organization|consumer organisations]] when developing standards that are relevant to consumer interests. CEN/CENELEC Guide 2 is older than Guide 6 and therefore does not reference it. At the end of 2004, CEN adopted a "Mechanism on the use of the CEN/CENELEC Guide 6"CEN: [http://www.cen.eu/Boss/supporting/guidance+documents/gd+-+mechanism+on+the+use+of+guide+6/index.asp Guidance - Mechanism on the use of the CEN/CENELEC Guide 6 'Guidelines for standards developers to address the needs of older persons and persons with disabilities']. Version 1 (January 2005). Accessed 2009-04-24.CEN: [http://www.cen.eu/boss/supporting/reference+documents/bt+resolutions+taken+in+2004.asp#58_2004 Resolution BT 58/2004: CEN/CLC Guide 6 - Mechanism]. Resolution applicable as from 2004-12-14. Accessed 2009-04-24. According to [[ANEC (organization)|ANEC]] it took two years to develop this mechanism and its adoption followed after "intense lobbying by ANEC".Gottlobe Fabisch: "[http://www.iso.org/sites/ConsumersStandards/en/pdf/ISO%20Focus%20July-August%202005-2-%20Giving%20more%20to%20older%20and%20disabled%20people.pdf ISO/IEC Guide 71 - Progress in Europe]" in ''ISO Focus'' July–August 2005, p. 24. Accessed 2009-06-26. The implementation mechanism has several implications: # CEN technical bodies (such as Technical Committees and Working Groups) are responsible for addressing the needs of older persons and of persons with disabilities in their standards. They can do this by creating an optional working document that is not part of the standard. (Not every standard is affected by the mechanism.) # When a standard is reviewed, the technical body can address the needs of older persons and persons with disabilities if necessary. When creating a new standard, these needs can be addressed during the standardisation work. # When appropriate, a technical body can add a statement in the foreword of a standard that states where the needs of older persons and persons with disabilities have been addressed. # The primary reference document that technical bodies should use when addressing the needs of older persons and persons with disabilities in their work is CEN/CENELEC Guide 6. CEN/CENELEC Guide 11: "Product information relevant to consumers - Guidelines for standard developers" was published in 2006 and refers to CEN/CENELEC Guide 6 for guidance on informational needs of people with disabilities and older people.CEN/CENELEC: [http://www.cen.eu/boss/supporting/reference+documents/cenclcguide11version1august2006.pdf CEN/CENELEC Guide 11: Product information relevant to consumers - Guidelines for standard developers]. Accessed 2009-06-24. In 2006 CEN sent a questionnaire on the use of Guide 6 to its technical committees. The results showed that 3 out of 275 CEN committees used the Guide 6. ANEC decided to propose to CEN how to take an initiative to change the situation.ANEC: [http://doksenter.custompublish.com/getfile.php/545555.951.edspuwfqsc/15th+ANEC+Design+for+All+Working+group+meeting+18th+September+2007..doc 15th ANEC Design for All Working group meeting 18th September 2007]. Consulted 2009-09-14. In 2007-2008, NEN - the Dutch standardisation organisation - and Standard Norge carried out a feasibility study within the European Mandate M/371. One of the findings was that the implementation of Guide 6 faced some difficulties. For this reason, NEN and CEN started an action to promote the use of Guide 6, and in December 2007 NEN proposed the installation of an CEN/CENELEC/BT/WG Accessibility for All.{{lang|nl|Nederlands Normalisatie-instituut}} (NEN), {{lang|no|Standard Norge}} (SN), {{lang|it|Ente nazional Italiano de Unificazione}} (UNI), {{lang|sl|Slovenski Institut za standardizacijo}} (SIST): [http://www.cen.eu/CENORM/sectors/business+development/value/project11smarthouseservices.pdf M/371 - Project 11: Smart House Services for Elderly and Disabled People - Final report 2008-09-30]. Accessed 2009-06-26. [[ANEC (organization)|ANEC]] also supported the creation of such a working group.ANEC: [http://www.anec.org/anec.asp?rd=7747&ref=02-01.01-01&lang=en&ID=226 Newsletter Number 94 – February 2008] (scroll down to "ANEC supports creation of CEN/BT Working Group ‘Accessibility for All’"). Accessed 2009-06-26. This led to the creation of the CEN/CENELEC/BT/WG ''CEN/CENELEC Guide 6 Implementation Mechanism''. The working group held a preliminary meeting on 29 October 2008Richard Hodgkinson: [http://www.tiresias.org/research/standards/report_9.htm 9th Report on International ICT Accessibility Standards Proposed, Being Developed and Recently Published], 2 April 2009. Accessed 2009-06-26.ANEC: [http://www.anec.org/anec.asp?rd=453&ref=02-01.01-01&lang=en&ID=236 Newsletter Number 98 –November 2008] (scroll down to "Accessibility for All and CEN/CENELEC Guide 6"). Accessed 2009-06-26. and its first official meeting on 8 April 2009.CEN: [http://www.cen.eu/CENORM/Sectors/news/archive/censectornews200903.pdf CEN Sector News], March 2009. The working group is here called: "CEN/CENELEC/BT/WG ''CEN/CENELEC Guide 6 Implementation Mechanism''". Accessed 2009-06-26.CEN: [http://www.cen.eu/cenorm/sectors/news/archive/censectornews200904.pdf CEN Sector News], April 2009. The working group is here called: "CEN/CENELEC/BT/WG ''CEN/CENELEC Guide 6: Guidelines for standards developers to address the needs of older persons and persons with disabilities - Implementation Mechanism''". Accessed 2009-06-26. In August 2008, the European Commission published a call for tenders on the subject of "Training of Stakeholders on consultations on standardisation"European Commission: Employment, Social Affairs and Equal Opportunities: [http://ec.europa.eu/social/main.jsp?catId=626&langId=en&callId=173&furtherCalls=yes Call for Tenders VT/ 2008/002: Training of Stakeholders on consultations on standardisation]. Published in Official Journal no. 2008/S 161-216866 on 21 August 2008. Accessed 2009-04-24. The main goal of this call is promoting the use of Guide 6:
A guide for standardisers to address the needs of older persons and persons with disabilities (CEN/CENELEC Guide 6), has been developed and is available since 2003 but its use is not widespread. The use of Guide 6 in a more systematic way can certainly help to address the needs of people with disabilities and older persons from a "design for all" perspective.European Commission: Employment, Social Affairs and Equal Opportunities: [http://ec.europa.eu/social/BlobServlet?docId=1331&langId=en Call for Tenders VT/ 2008/002: Tender Specifications (PDF)]. Accessed 2009-04-24.
The use of the guide should be promoted by training two types of stakeholders in the standardisation process: # the traditional stakeholders in the standardisation process need training on accessibility matters and the use of Guide 6; # representatives of older persons and persons with disabilities need training on the standardisation process (and CEN/CENELEC Guide 6). The European project [[USEM]] (User Empowerment in Standardisation)[http://www.usem-net.eu/ USEM: User Empowerment in Standardisation]. Project co-funded by the European Commission within the Sixth Framework Programme. Accessed 2009-04-24. also used CEN/CENELEC Guide 6 in its training on standardisation for representatives of older persons and persons with disabilities.{{lang|de|Christian Bühler}}: "[http://www.springerlink.com/content/f5672058j25xg806/ Users with Disabilities and Standards]". ''Computers Helping People with Special Needs. Proceedings of ICCHP 2008.'' Lecture Notes in Computer Science (LNCS) 4061. Edited by {{lang|de|Miesenberger}} et al. Berlin: Springer, 2008. P. 162-165. ==Translations== CEN/CENELEC Guide 6 is also available in other languages, usually as a translation of ISO/IEC Guide 71, for example: * Dutch: NPR-ISO/IEC Guide 71:2002 nl: {{lang|nl|Richtlijnen voor normontwikkelaars voor de aanpak van de behoeftes van oudere personen en personen met een handicap}},NEN: [http://www2.nen.nl/nen/servlet/dispatcher.Dispatcher?id=BIBLIOGRAFISCHEGEGEVENS&contentID=157832 {{lang|nl|Richtlijnen voor normontwikkelaars voor de aanpak van de behoeftes van oudere personen en personen met een handicap}}]. Accessed 2009-09-29. * French: {{lang|fr|FD ISO/CEI GUIDE 71 Août 2002: Principes directeurs pour les normalisateurs afin de répondre aux besoins des personnes âgées et de celles ayant des incapacités}},AFNOR: [http://www.boutique.afnor.org/NEL5DetailNormeEnLigne.aspx?&nivCtx=NELZNELZ1A10A101A107&ts=2162122&CLE_ART=FA123851 {{lang|fr|FD ISO/CEI GUIDE 71 Août 2002: Principes directeurs pour les normalisateurs afin de répondre aux besoins des personnes âgées et de celles ayant des incapacités}}]. Accessed 2009-09-29. * German: {{lang|de|DIN-Fachbericht 131: Leitlinien für Normungsgremien zur Berücksichtigung der Bedürfnisse von älteren Menschen und von Menschen mit Behinderungen; Deutsche und englische Fassung des CEN/CENELEC-Leitfadens 6}}, * Norwegian: SN-ISO/IEC Guide 71:2001: {{lang|no|Retningslinjer for å ta hensyn til eldres og funksjonshemmedes behov ved utarbeidelse av standarder}},Standard.no: [http://www.standard.no/no/Sok-og-kjop/produktkatalogen/Produktpresentasjon/?ProductId=146089 SN-ISO/IEC Guide 71:2001: {{lang|no|Retningslinjer for å ta hensyn til eldres og funksjonshemmedes behov ved utarbeidelse av standarder}}]. Accessed 2009-09-16. * Swedish: {{lang|sv|Riktlinjer för att i standardiseringsarbetet tillgodose behoven hos äldre och personer med funktionsnedsättningar}},Swedish Standards Institute (SIS): [http://www.hi.se/Global/pdf/2006/Guide6.pdf SIS-CEN/CENELEC Guide 6:2006]. Accessed 2009-06-26. * Japanese: JIS Z 8071:2003.According to ISO/IEC JTC 1/SC 7/WG 2: [http://www.incits.org/tc_home/ia/ia050043.pdf Contribution from JTC 1/SC 7/WG 2 on Current IT Accessibility Standards Activities] ([http://www.jtc1access.org/documents/J1N7751.pdf alternative location]). Accessed 2009-06-26. ==See also== * [[Accessibility]] * [[Universal Design]] * [[Design for All (design philosophy)]] * [[Design for All (in ICT)]] * [[Assistive technology]] * [[Computer accessibility]] * [[Standardization]] ==References== {{RE}} {{List of EN standards|state=autocollapse}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Cen Cenelec Guide 6}} [[Category:Accessibility]] [[Category:EN standards]] [[Category:Ergonomics]]

revision.comment: Reverted [[WP:AGF|good faith]] edits by [[Special:Contributions/176.18.79.101|176.18.79.101]] ([[User talk:176.18.79.101|talk]]): If you change a fact, you must provide a new source . ([[WP:TW|TW]])
revision.text:
'''Cannabis in Saudi Arabia''' is illegal.
==Enforcement== Use and possession of [[cannabis]] is illegal in [[Saudi Arabia]]. Use and possession for personal use of any kind of recreational drugs is often punishable by imprisonment if caught. For Saudi citizens, there would generally be more leniency. Imprisonment for personal use of cannabis could go up to 1 to 6 months in prison with or without [[judicial corporal punishment|whippings]] for first time offenders. Imprisonment for drug dealing can range between 2 to 10 years in prison with whippings. Repeated dealing and or smuggling of high amounts of drugs usually result in harsher time in prison or even the death penalty, although recently executions are rare. Foreigners who use drugs might be deported.<ref>{{citation |url = https://travel.state.gov/travel/cis_pa_tw/cis/cis_1012.html |title = US Department of State – International Travel – Saudi Arabia |publisher = Travel.state.gov |date = |accessdate = 2011-02-17 }}</ref>
In 2003, the [[UNODC]] rated Saudi Arabia as third globally in its measures to fight drug abuse and trafficking.<ref name="Maisel">{{cite book|author=Sebastian Maisel|title=Saudi Arabia and the Gulf Arab States Today: An Encyclopedia of Life in the Arab States|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=uhJu2_8vMkMC&pg=PA124|publisher=Greenwood Press|isbn=978-0-313-34442-8|pages=124–}}</ref>
==Economy== [[Hashish]] in Saudi Arabia is largely trafficked by sea from [[Pakistan]]; a 2007 report notes that hashish sold for US$2,130 per kilogram.<ref name="Leghari2007">{{cite book|author=Faryal Leghari|title=Narcotics and Human Trafficking to the GCC States|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=i_NWAAAAYAAJ|year=2007|publisher=Gulf Research Center|isbn=978-9948-434-27-6|page=53}}</ref>
==References== {{reflist}}

page.title: Capital punishment in the United Arab Emirates

revision.comment: de-embolden per [[MOS:TITLEABSENTBOLD]]
revision.text:
{{refimprove|date=January 2016}} {{Use dmy dates|date=May 2014}} [[Capital punishment]] is a legal penalty in the [[United Arab Emirates]], although it is rarely carried out.
Under Emirati law, multiple crimes carry the death penalty, and the sole method of execution is firing squad. Current law theoretically allows the death penalty for [[treason]], [[espionage]], [[murder]], successfully inciting the [[suicide]] of a person "afflicted with total lack of free will or reason", [[arson]] resulting in death, acts of indecent [[assault]] resulting in death, importing nuclear substances/wastes in the environment of the State, [[adultery]], [[apostasy]], [[blasphemy]], [[perjury]] causing wrongful execution, [[rape]], [[aggravated robbery]], [[kidnapping]], [[terrorism]], [[sodomy]], [[homosexuality]], [[drug trafficking]]<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.deathpenaltyworldwide.org/country-search-post.cfm?country=United+Arab+Emirates|title=The Death Penalty in United Arab Emirates|publisher=Death Penalty Worldwide|accessdate=25 August 2017}}</ref> and joining the [[Islamic State of Iraq and the Levant]]<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.alaraby.co.uk/english/news/2016/2/15/uae-sentences-four-to-death-for-joining-is|title=UAE sentences four to death for joining IS|publisher=The New Arab|date=15 February 2016|accessdate=6 December 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.alaraby.co.uk/english/news/2016/1/10/uae-sentences-jihadi-teenager-to-death-for-joining-is|title=UAE sentences 'jihadi teenager' to death for joining IS|publisher=The New Arab|date=10 January 2016|accessdate=6 December 2017}}</ref>, although death sentences are frequently commuted to [[life sentence]]s. Overseas nationals and UAE nationals have both been executed for crimes.
==Notable cases==
In 1995, [[Sarah Balabagan]], a Filipino worker, caught the attention of many people living in the UAE. She was reported to have murdered her employer in his Al Ain house, although she has always maintained that she only killed him in self-defence after he tried to rape her. After the UAE president himself got involved, Balabagan was set free and had to pay compensation instead. However, she was deported back to her country and her right to remain in the country was cancelled.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.corpun.com/aeju9510.htm|title=Judicial caning, Arab Emirates, Oct 1995 - CORPUN ARCHIVE aeju9510|publisher=}}</ref>
In June 2015, the [[Federal Supreme Court of the United Arab Emirates|Federal Supreme Court]] sentenced an Emirati [[terrorist]] woman, Alaa Bader al-Hashemi, to the death penalty for the [[murder of Ibolya Ryan]] and planting a "handmade bomb" in an Egyptian-American doctor's home in Abu Dhabi. The woman committed the crime in December 2014 and was executed at dawn on July 13, 2015.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://tribune.com.pk/story/911760/uae-woman-sentenced-to-death-for-killing-us-teacher/|title=UAE woman sentenced to death for killing US teacher|work=Express Tribune|date=29 June 2015|accessdate=30 June 2015}}</ref> This is the only time that a prisoner has been executed within such a short time frame and this is the one of the few cases of a woman being executed.
On 23 November 2017 Nidal Eisa Abdullah, the convict who raped and killed eight-year-old boy Obaida in May 2016, was executed. <ref>{{cite news|url=http://gulfnews.com/news/uae/courts/man-who-raped-killed-eight-year-old-boy-obaida-executed-1.2129225/|title=UAE man executed}}</ref>
==References== {{Reflist}} == See also == *[[Crime in the United Arab Emirates]] *[[Legal system of the United Arab Emirates]] ==External links== *[http://www.deathpenaltyworldwide.org/country-search-post.cfm?country=United+Arab+Emirates Death Penalty Worldwide: United Arab Emirates] {{Capital punishment}} {{Asia in topic|Capital punishment in}} [[Category:Capital punishment by country|United Arab Emirates]] [[Category:Crime in the United Arab Emirates]] [[Category:Emirati law]]

revision.text:
{{Infobox university | name = CENTRAL MEDICAL COLLEGE | native_name = সেন্ট্রাল মেডিকেল কলেজ | native_name_lang = bn | nickname = CeMeC | image = | image_size = | image_alt = | caption = | other_name = <!-- or: | other_names = --> | former_name = <!-- or: | former_names = --> | established = {{start date|2005}} | type = [[Private university|Private]] [[medical school]] | academic_affiliation = [[University of Chittagong]] | chairman = Dr. [[Syed Abdullah Muhammad Taher]] | principal = Dr. Shofiqur Rahman Patwary | academic_staff = | administrative_staff = | students = | undergrad = | postgrad = | doctoral = | other = | city = Paduar Bazar, Bishaw Road | state = [[Comilla]] | country = [[Bangladesh]] | coor = {{Coord|23.4119|N|91.1844|E|region:BD_type:edu|display=inline,title}} | affiliations = [[University of Chittagong]], [[Ministry of Health and Family Welfare (Bangladesh)]], [[Bangladesh Medical and Dental Council]] | campus = [[Rural area|Rural]] | language = English | website = {{URL|cemecbd.com}} | footnotes = }} '''CENTRAL MEDICAL COLLEGE''' ('''CeMeC''') ({{lang-bn|সেন্ট্রাল মেডিকেল কলেজ}}) is a [[Private university|private]] [[medical school]] in [[Bangladesh]], established in 2005. The main campus is located beside the Dhaka–Chittagong Highway at Paduar Bazar, Bishaw Road in [[Comilla Sadar Dakshin Upazila]], in the [[Comilla District]] of [[Chittagong Division]]. It is affiliated with [[University of Chittagong]], [[Ministry of Health and Family Welfare (Bangladesh)]] and [[Bangladesh Medical and Dental Council]].
It offers a five-year course of study leading to a [[Bachelor of Medicine, Bachelor of Surgery]] (MBBS) degree. A one-year [[internship]] after [[graduation]] is compulsory for all graduates.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.cemecbd.com/?page_id=88 |title=MBBS Course |website=Central Medical College |access-date=8 March 2017}}</ref> The degree is recognised by the [[Bangladesh Medical and Dental Council]].
==History== Central Medical College was established in 2005.
==Campus== The main campus is located beside the Dhaka–Chittagong Highway at Paduar Bazar, Bishaw Road in [[Comilla Sadar Dakshin Upazila]], in the [[Comilla District]] of [[Chittagong Division]].
==Organization and administration== It is affiliated with [[University of Chittagong]], [[Ministry of Health and Family Welfare (Bangladesh)]] and [[Bangladesh Medical and Dental Council]] The college is affiliated with [[University of Chittagong]], [[Ministry of Health and Family Welfare (Bangladesh)]] and [[Bangladesh Medical and Dental Council]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.cemecbd.com/?page_id=83 |title=Affiliated Colleges |website=Central Medical College |access-date=8 March 2017}}</ref> The chairman of the college is Dr. [[Syed Abdullah Muhammad Taher]] and The principal is Dr. Shofiqur Rahman Patwary.
==Academics== The college offers a five-year course of study, approved by the [[Bangladesh Medical and Dental Council]] (BMDC), leading to a [[Bachelor of Medicine, Bachelor of Surgery]] (MBBS) degree from Chittagong University. After passing the final professional examination, there is a compulsory one-year [[internship]]. The internship is a prerequisite for obtaining registration from the BMDC to practice medicine.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://bmdc.org.bd/recognized-medical-and-dental-colleges/ |title=List of Recognized medical and dental colleges |website=Bangladesh Medical & Dental Council}}</ref>
==See also== * [[List of medical colleges in Bangladesh]] * [[List of Educational Institutions in Comilla]]
==References== {{Reflist}}
{{Private Medical Colleges of Bangladesh}}

{{Bangladesh-edu-stub}}
